blocks.text: Florida - continued

Left - Near Copperhill, Tenn., miles of barren soil cut by deep gullies, said to be caused by fumes in copper refining. Below left - Partially completed memorial to armed forces of the Confederacy on Stone Mountain, sixteen miles from Atlanta; Stone Mountain rises baldly 800 feet above the surrounding country; it is more than seven miles in circumference. Below center - Time out for a shave. Below right - Large snake which had been run over by a preceding car.
"WAY DOWN UPON THE SUWANNEE RIVER"

Left and above - We crossed the Suwannee River near Branford, Fla. Right and bel ow - A swim at St. Augustine, one of two oldest cities in United States. Below - One of many black, ugly Florida swamps, and ruins of a Florida mission.

TRIP TO the GREAT SMOKIES and the SEASHORE
Kitty and Gordon — 1936
Route: to York; to Frederick, Md.; to Leesburg, Va.; to New Market; down Shenandoah Valley to Johnson City, Tenn; to Seviererville; across the Great Smokies; to Asheville, N.C; to Winston-Salem; to Norfolk, Va; across Chesapeake Bay to Cape Charles; to Chincoteague Island; to Salisbury, Md; to Rehoboth Beach for a swim; across the Delaware River at New Castle; to Atlantic City; and home.

blocks.text:
Market; Sevier
to Winston Cape Ch
Rehoboth New Cast

With the creation of a magnificent new high-way over the Great Smokies, the Great Smoky Mountains National Park has become the most visited national park in the United States. This great new park embraces 700 square miles of the most massive mountain system in East- ern America. For a distance of about 75 miles the park straddles the high range of the Southern Appalachian Mountains which form the border between Tennessee and North Carolina. Twenty peaks in the park are over 6000 feet high.

blocks.text: Wedding trip - continued

Above - Bathing at Miami Beach, where we spent two days. In the second picture, note that the "stranger" appears to be losing his trunks; also note smoke from ship in the distance. Miami is located farther south than any point on the Mediterranean, which explains the wide variety of tropical vegetation. In August, 1937 most of the large ocean-front hotels were practically deserted, so we were able to secure a room with bath, overlooking a Spanish court, in an ocean-front hotel for $1.50 per night for two. At Miami we visited Alice and Lou Wentworth, former Pennsylvanians, and spent a night touring the spots of interest.

Above, left to right - Beautiful palm studded parks separate the beach from the drive in Miami Beach. We took a seaplane ride over Miami and Miami Beach; plane is in Biscayne Bay, along the south causeway. Airplane view of "man-made" islands in Biscayne Bay. The Miami-Biltmore Hotel at Coral Gables. Miami Beach is a separate city from Miami located on an island seven miles long and one-half mile wide. The municipality is separated from the City of Miami by Biscayne Bay, over which it is reached by three causeways. The spark-ling waters of Biscayne Bay furnish snug retreat for watercraft of all kinds.

blocks.text:
Left and right – on a bluff overlooking Pensacola Bay. Pensacola has one of the largest and finest natural harbors in North America. The site was first visited by Miruela in 1516, 24 years after Columbus discovered America. Forty three years later the first permanent settlement was founded by Don Tristram de Luna. The city has flown five flags, and has undergone seventeen changes of government. Quaint old houses, forts and dungeons passages recall early conflicts between Spanish and French.
U.S. Naval Air Base, near the Bay entrance, which we visited, maintains the largest naval training school.
Cochrane Bridge, a ten miles stretch of bridges and earthworks over Mobile Bay, on the Spanish Trail.
Barton Academy, used as a hospital during the Civil War, Mobile.
Along the Gulf of Mex-ico at Biloxi, Miss.

Mexican restaurant where we ate an assortment of Mexican dishes, many of them too "hot" to be palatable. New Orleans.
(taken in the rain)

The Long-Simmons Bridg-
e across the eastern part of Lake Ponchar- train, nearing New Orleans, La.

Jackson Square and St. Louis Cathedral (1794), one of the oldest churches in America. Jackson Square is one of the most historic spots in America. Here La. territory was transferred to Spain and later to the United States in 1803. New Orleans.

blocks.text: Scenes in The Great Smoky Mountains National Park. Many parts have never been seen by white men. The Park includes the largest and finest virgin hardwood forests in the United States and the greatest untouched forest of red spruce. Nowhere in the world is there such a variety of plant life in an equal area. Inviting trails wind through many sections, one of which is shown above.

Forney Ridge, elevation
6310 ft., is reached by a return-the-same-way road from Newfound Gap. It is the highest point reached by a public highway in eastern U.S.
FORNEY RIDGE ELEVATION 6.310
Sight seeing buses on Forney Ridge. Most passengers view the park standing up through the cut-out tops.
View of the Great Smokies from an el- doration of 6000 ft.

Ample parking space
is found on Forney Ridge.

blocks.text: "Twin Chimneys" tower high above the wind-ing highway as the descent is made into Tennessee from New-found Gap.

A last look at the Gr-
eat Smokies, which can be seen faintly in the
distance.

A waterfall in the Gr-
eat Smokies. Note the
resemblance to a dog's head.

The road winds and crosses itself to red-
uce the severity of
the grade on the Tenn-
essee side.

Almost home - view at Harpers Ferry, picturesquely situated where Maryland, West Virginia and Virginia touch borders.
This was the scene of John Br-owned's famous raid, when he hoped to incite slaves to revolt and to arm them from the government arsenal.
End of Wedded Trip.

blocks.text: QUEBEC sitting majestically on its rock is a bit of old Normandy in a new setting. It has a population of 140,000, is the only walled city in North America, and is the second oldest city in America. It is divided into two distinct parts, the Upper Town, built entirely on the cliff, and the Lower Town, spread out on the shore surround- ing Cape Diamond and well up into
Chateau Frontenac Fromonttenaac, Quebecbec, Quebeec, world-famed hostelry

Monument to Champlain,
founder of the city of Quebec.
View of the Lower Town and the St. Lawrence from Dufferin Terrace.

blocks.text: Beyond Ste. Anne de Beaupré we traversed a gravel road which scales the Laurentides and runs along their crest practically the whole way to St. Simeon. Only at three places does the road descend to the shores of the St. Lawrence. Hills were abrupt, and on many occasions we were forced into low gear. The broad waters of the St. Lawrence were frequently visible. Most of the parishes along this north shore are more than two centuries old, and the people are deeply religious. La Malbaie with its Manoir Richelieu is one of the most fashionable resorts in Canada.

As we descend the Laurentides,
the quaint little town of Les
E boulements lies at our feet,
with the waters of the St. Law-
rence stretching beyond.

blocks.text:
At St. Simeon (114 miles from Que-
bec) we waited two houres for a
train to take us on the last leg of our journey.

At St. Simeon (114 miles from Que-bec) we waited two hours for the ferry to carry us across the river to Riviere du Loup. The ferry, sh-owned at the right, finally arrived. The crossing required two hours, and the cost for four was $9.50. The party of four was exactly twenty-four cars, and we were number twen-ty-two in line. Had we been unable to get aboard, it would have meant a wait of two days for the next trip or a return to Quebec and a trip up the south shore from there. Below - Kitty and Myrtle on board.

Left - making friends
with a large dog near
Bic, where we were
given an account of
the severe winters.

blocks.text: Almost every home on the Gaspe has its out-door masonry oven. Fire is kept inside the oven until the thick walls are thoroughly heated; then the coals are raked out and in goes the dough to be baked into bread by fireless heat.

blocks.text: The highway fringes rugged Gaspe promontories along the north shore. These pictures were taken near Mount Louis. These towering precipices ex-tend for miles and an occasional stream dashes down. The highway here is built on a causeway of rock and heavy timber to protect it from the tide. These are the headlands of the mighty Appalachian chain which stretch 3000 miles to the Gulf of Mexico.
From a high point near Riviere-aux-Renards we caught a glimpse of Anti-costi Island lying forty to fifty miles out in the Gulf.

Dozens of tiny hamlets dot the St. Lawrence shore. Each one is sure to have its church spire standing out against the sky. The scenery is ruggedly beautiful, with frowning crags and spots where the water can be seen a thousand feet below.

blocks.text: Gaspe - continued

Friendly, smiling children of the Gaspe, impelled by a natural curiosity, climbed on the running board of our car at every village we stopped. Some of these children, spoiled by tourists, would beg for money, candy, and some of the older ones for cigarettes.

Above - we spent a night in these cabins near Madeleine.
Left - dogs hitched to carts are a common sight on the Gaspe.
Right - a glorified oven, with a wooden roof, near Madeleine.

Composite picture (a double exposure) of Cape Gaspe Station and the nearby cliffs.

nearin St. Majorique and Gaspe Town.
The fishing boats look like toys on the placid waters of the
Bay. Note Perce Rock far in the distance. Here white men first landed on Canadian soil when Cartier sailed into Gaspe Bay to escape a storm during the summer of 1534.

blocks.text:
Mount Ste. Anne, which forms the background for Perce, is a remnant of a much larger mountain, which it is said split in some unknown age past, part of it tumbling down to form Perce Rock.
To the right are views of the road in the valley back of Perce and separated from Perce by Mount Ste. Anne.
Bert. Labbee Marchand

Above - after driving along the south side of the Peninsula , along Baie des Chaleurs, with the mountains faintly in the distance, we prepare to leave the Province of Quebec by embarking on the ferry to Camp-bellton, N. B.
Left – we stopped for supplies at this store, where the proprietor and his wife spoke only French.

blocks.text: In New Brunswick the road south from Campbellton to Moncton passes through a great forest wilderness. We encountered rain on a rough road without a hard surface cut straight through the for- ests. A look at the map discloses practically nothing for miles to the west of the road. We spent the night at Moncton, and the next morning watched the inrushing waters of the tides of the Bay of Fundy, known as "The Bore". The road from Moncton to St. John, by contrast, was excellent. (For an account of the Reversing Falls at St. John, see trip in 1936.)
